txt: Clarence Day, American author and illustrator (b. 1874)

entities.title: Clarence Day
entities.description: Clarence Shepard Day Jr. was an American author and cartoonist, best known for his 1935 work Life with Father.

heading: Deaths
txt: Maurice Ravel, French pianist and composer (b. 1875)

entities.title: Maurice Ravel
entities.description: Joseph Maurice Ravel was a French composer, pianist and conductor. He is often associated with impressionism along with his elder contemporary Claude Debussy, although both composers rejected the term. In the 1920s and 1930s Ravel was internationally regarded as France's greatest living composer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Florence Lawrence, Canadian actress (b. 1886)

entities.title: Florence Lawrence
entities.description: Florence Lawrence was a Canadian-American stage performer and film actress. She is often referred to as the "first movie star", and was thought to be the first film actor to be named publicly until evidence published in 2019 indicated that the first named film star was French actor Max Linder. At the height of her fame in the 1910s, she was known as the "Biograph Girl" for work as one of the leadi

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred Flatow, German gymnast (b. 1869)

entities.title: Alfred Flatow
entities.description: Alfred Flatow was a German gymnast. He competed at the 1896 Summer Olympics in Athens. He was Jewish.

heading: Deaths
txt: Steve Evans, American baseball player (b. 1885)

entities.title: Steve Evans (baseball)
entities.description: Louis Richard (Steve) Evans was a right fielder in Major League Baseball.

heading: Deaths
txt: Theodore Dreiser, American novelist and journalist (b. 1871)

entities.title: Theodore Dreiser
entities.description: Theodore Herman Albert Dreiser was an American novelist and journalist of the naturalist school. His novels often featured main characters who succeeded at their objectives despite a lack of a firm moral code, and literary situations that more closely resemble studies of nature than tales of choice and agency. Dreiser's best known novels include Sister Carrie (1900) and An American Tragedy (1925).

entities.title: Elie Nadelman
entities.description: Elie Nadelman was a Polish-American sculptor, draughtsman and collector of folk art.

entities.description: Victor Emmanuel III reigned as King of Italy from 29 July 1900 until his abdication on 9 May 1946. In addition, he was Emperor of Ethiopia (1936–1941) and King of the Albanians (1939–1943). During his reign of nearly 46 years, which began after the assassination of his father Umberto I, the Kingdom of Italy became involved in two world wars. entities.title: Jack Lovelock

Pavelić and the Ustaše persecuted many racial minorities and political

entities.title: World War II
entities.description: World War II or the Second World War, often abbreviated as WWII or WW2, was a global war that lasted from 1939 to 1945. It involved the vast majority of the world's countries—including all the great powers—forming two opposing military alliances: the Allies and the Axis powers. heading: Deaths
txt: Philippe Panneton, Canadian physician, academic, and diplomat (b. 1895)

entities.title: Philippe Panneton
entities.description: Philippe Panneton was a Canadian physician, academic, diplomat and writer.

txt: Paul Hindemith, German violinist, composer, and conductor (b. 1895)

entities.description: Paul Hindemith was a prolific German composer, violist, violinist, teacher and conductor. In the 1920s, he became a major advocate of the Neue Sachlichkeit style of music. Notable compositions include his song cycle Das Marienleben (1923), Der Schwanendreher for viola and orchestra (1935), and the opera Mathis der Maler (1938). Hindemith's most popular work, both on record and in the concert hall,

heading: Deaths
txt: Katharine McCormick, American biologist and philanthropist (b. 1875)

entities.title: Katharine McCormick
entities.description: Katharine Dexter McCormick was a U.S. suffragist, philanthropist and, after her husband's death, heir to a substantial part of the McCormick family fortune. She funded most of the research necessary to develop the first birth control pill.

heading: Deaths
txt: David Ogilvy, 12th Earl of Airlie, Scottish peer, soldier and courtier (b. 1893)

entities.title: David Ogilvy, 12th Earl of Airlie
entities.description: Colonel David Lyulph Gore Wolseley Ogilvy, 12th and 7th Earl of Airlie was a Scottish peer, soldier, and courtier.

heading: Deaths
txt: Max Steiner, Austrian-American pianist, composer, and conductor (b. 1888)

entities.title: Max Steiner
entities.description: Maximilian Raoul Steiner was an Austrian-born American music composer for theatre and films, as well as a conductor. He was a child prodigy who conducted his first operetta when he was twelve and became a full-time professional, either composing, arranging, or conducting, when he was fifteen.

heading: Deaths
txt: Katharine Byron, American politician (b. 1903)

entities.title: Katharine Byron
entities.description: Katharine Edgar Byron, a Democrat, was a U.S. Congresswoman who represented the 6th congressional district of Maryland from May 27, 1941 to January 3, 1943. She was the first woman elected to Congress from Maryland.

heading: Deaths
txt: Allan Dwan, Canadian-American director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1885)

entities.title: Allan Dwan
entities.description: Allan Dwan was a pioneering Canadian-born American motion picture director, producer, and screenwriter.

Demarest became a prolific film and television actor, appearing in over 140 films, beginning in 1927 and ending in the 1970s. He frequently played crusty but good-hearted roles.

txt: William L. Shirer, American journalist and historian (b. 1904)

entities.title: William L. Shirer
entities.description: William Lawrence Shirer was an American journalist and war correspondent. He wrote The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich, a history of Nazi Germany that has been read by many and cited in scholarly works for more than 50 years. txt: Jean-Louis Lévesque, Canadian businessman and philanthropist (b. 1911)

entities.title: Jean-Louis Lévesque
entities.description: Jean-Louis Lévesque, was a Canadian entrepreneur, thoroughbred racehorse owner, and philanthropist.

entities.title: Clayton Moore
entities.description: Clayton Moore was an American actor best known for playing the fictional western character the Lone Ranger from 1949 to 1952 and 1953 to 1957 on the television series of the same name and two related movies from the same producers.

entities.title: Samuel Abraham Goldblith
entities.description: Samuel Abraham Goldblith was an American food scientist. While involved in World War II, he studied malnutrition, and later was involved in food research important for space exploration.

entities.description: Rear Admiral Benjamin Thurman Hacker (1935–2003) was a U.S. Navy officer, who became the first Naval Flight Officer (NFO) to achieve Flag rank.

entities.title: Jerry Orbach
entities.description: Jerome Bernard Orbach was an American actor and singer, described at the time of his death as "one of the last bona fide leading men of the Broadway musical and global celebrity on television" and a "versatile stage and film actor".

heading: Deaths
txt: Irene Lieblich, Polish-American painter and illustrator (b. 1923)

entities.title: Irene Lieblich
entities.description: Irene Lieblich was a Polish-born artist and Holocaust survivor noted for illustrating the books of Nobel laureate Isaac Bashevis Singer and for her paintings highlighting Jewish life and culture. She is also a distant cousin of noted Yiddish language author and playwright Isaac Leib Peretz.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jimmy Sullivan, American musician, composer and songwriter. Known by his stage name The Rev (b. 1981)

entities.title: The Rev
entities.description: James "Jimmy" Owen Sullivan, also known by his stage name The Rev, was an American musician. Best known as the drummer of heavy metal band Avenged Sevenfold, The Rev was widely regarded and critically acclaimed for his work on the band's albums, and contributed entire songs composed by himself, such as "Afterlife", "A Little Piece of Heaven", and "Almost Easy".

entities.title: Billy Taylor
entities.description: Billy Taylor was an American jazz pianist, composer, broadcaster and educator. He was the Robert L. Jones Distinguished Professor of Music at East Carolina University in Greenville, and from 1994 was the artistic director for jazz at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicholas Ambraseys, Greek-English seismologist and engineer (b. 1929)

entities.title: Nicholas Ambraseys
entities.description: Nicholas Neocles Ambraseys FICE FREng was a Greek engineering seismologist. He was emeritus professor of Engineering Seismology and Senior Research Fellow at Imperial College London. For many years Ambraseys was considered as the leading figure and an authority in earthquake engineering and seismology in Europe.

entities.title: IMAP
entities.description: In computing, the Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) is an Internet standard protocol used by email clients to retrieve email messages from a mail server over a TCP/IP connection. IMAP is defined by RFC 3501.

txt: Alfred Marshall, American businessman, founded Marshalls (b. 1919)

entities.title: Marshalls
entities.description: Marshalls is an American chain of off-price department stores owned by TJX Companies. Marshalls has over 1,000 American stores, including larger stores named Marshalls Mega Store, covering 42 states and Puerto Rico, and 61 stores in Canada. Marshalls first expanded into Canada in March 2011.

txt: Vahan Hovhannisyan, Armenian politician (b. 1956)

entities.title: Vahan Hovhannisyan
entities.description: Vahan Hovhannisyan was an Armenian politician of the Armenian Revolutionary Federation (ARF). He was Vice-President of the National Assembly of Armenia from 2007 to 2008 and was a candidate in the February 2008 presidential election. A 2008 leaked confidential document by the US State Department described him as "clearly the most likeable Dashnak by public persona."

entities.title: List of Governors of the Northern Mariana Islands
entities.description: The following is a list of persons who served as Governor of the Northern Mariana Islands. The term of office is 4 years. The longest-serving governors in CNMI history are Pedro Tenorio, who served 12 years in office from 1982 to 1990 and from 1998 to 2002, and Benigno Fitial, who served 7 years, one month, and 11 days from 2006 to 2013.
